msgs.text: STORING YOUR BITCOIN I had a tough time placing this channel in the "Experienced Topics" category because even though it involves some work, storing your Bitcoin safely isn't very hard...and the proper way to store your Bitcoin stack is probably the most important thing to know when it comes to Bitcoin knowledge. There are some best practices to follow that give you the best security and full control (ownership) of your Bitcoin. First of all, your coins should not be left on an exchange. As the saying goes, "not your keys, not your coins." What this means is that actually owning your Bitcoin means you are fully in control of your private keys that give you access to your digital property (your Bitcoin). By leaving your Bitcoin on an exchange, you are in essence trusting that exchange with your private keys. God forbid something happen to that exchange, they have the right to withhold your Bitcoin indefinitely, or worse, they could lose your coins permanently due to a hack or some related catastrophe. Your password for your bitcoin is what is known as your private keys. Never tell your private keys to anyone. Never store them on the internet or take a picture of them. If they are off the internet and not stored anywhere they can't be hacked. Instead. just write them down and store it in a safe (preferably fireproof). If you lose or forget your private keys, your coins are likely lost forever. However, I have learned about a service called KeychainX that works to recover forgotten pins. There may be hope if all else fails.

For the same reason above, you shouldn't use an online wallet to store your Bitcoin. These are called "hot wallets" (wallets stored on the internet in any way).The easiest thing you can do is purchase a cold storage device like a Trezor or a Keep Key. From there, as you gain experience, you can take additional steps to improve the security of your Bitcoin such as using a multisignature (multisig) wallet address as outlined here: https://armantheparman.com/bitcoin-storage-get-better/

PUBLIC KEY VS PRIVATE KEY *(under construction)* MULTI SIGNATURE WALLET *(under construction)* A multi signature (multisig) setup is one that avoids a single point of failure in a normal hardware wallet. For example, in a 2/3 multisig setup, if one wallet gets compromised or lost, your bitcoin can still be accessed by use of the other two wallets combined. Passphrases
- up to 50 characters
- recommended to use at least 4 random words (not all from the 2048 -bip39 word list) but also make the words memorable for you, so you don't forget them
- numbers, symbols and spaces all accepted

Using RANDOM English language words (~100,000 words)

4 words = log2(100,000^4) = 66 bits of entropy or 100 quintillion (100 with 18 zeros) combinations.

8 words = log2(100,000^8) = 132 bits of entropy or 10 duodecillion (10 with 39 zeros) combinations.
